definition: to run like the wind/to rush/to gallop
to run/to run away/to escape/to run around (on errands etc)/(of a gas or liquid) to leak or evaporate/(verb complement) away/off

sentences.english: Why, I always go down at full gallop.
sentences.chinese: 噢，我总是打着马飞跑下山的。

sentences.english: The horses were raring to have a gallop.
sentences.chinese: 这些马都急不可耐地要飞跑起来。

sentences.english: Their feet are swift to shed blood
sentences.chinese: 杀人流血他们的脚飞跑。

sentences.english: He grabbed the wheelchair and pushed her along.
sentences.chinese: 他一把抓过轮椅，推着她飞跑起来。

sentences.english: The children flew to meet their mother.
sentences.chinese: 孩子们飞跑过去迎接妈妈。

sentences.english: He opened one eye in time to see a tiny gray shadow whisk past.
sentences.chinese: 他睁开一只眼睛，看到一个小小的灰色影子飞跑过去。

sentences.english: He hared off down the road.
A car rolls into the village and children dash to meet it.
sentences.chinese: 一辆汽车驶进村庄，儿童们飞跑过去迎接。

sentences.english: Down the broad white road ran jack .
sentences.chinese: 杰克沿着白色宽阔大道飞跑。

sentences.english: The children ran to the barn.
sentences.chinese: 孩子们飞跑到谷仓去了。

sentences.english: White Flower flew out of doors and warned him.
sentences.chinese: 白花飞跑出门，向他发出了警报。

sentences.english: The little girl flew to her grandmother.
sentences.chinese: 这女孩向她奶奶飞跑过去。

definition: to take to one's heels/to scram
like a wisp of smoke/(to disappear etc) in an instant
rolling and crawling/trying frantically to escape (idiom)
(dialect) to rush off/to scamper off double-quick/to take to one's heels/to make oneself scarce
to run fast/to sprint/to gallop/Gee up!/Run for it!
